trans-unit.source: App Service API Apps metadata for API discovery and code generation | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: App Service API Apps metadata for API discovery and code generation | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how API Apps in Azure App Service use Swagger metadata to facilitate API discovery and code generation.
trans-unit.target: Learn how API Apps in Azure App Service use Swagger metadata to facilitate API discovery and code generation.

trans-unit.source: App Service API Apps metadata for API discovery and code generation
trans-unit.target: App Service API Apps metadata for API discovery and code generation

trans-unit.source: Support for [Swagger 2.0](http://swagger.io/) API metadata is built into App Service API Apps.
trans-unit.target: Support for [Swagger 2.0](http://swagger.io/) API metadata is built into App Service API Apps.

trans-unit.source: You don't have to use Swagger, but if you do use it, you can take advantage of API Apps features that make discovery and consumption easier.
trans-unit.target: You don't have to use Swagger, but if you do use it, you can take advantage of API Apps features that make discovery and consumption easier.

trans-unit.source: Swagger endpoint
trans-unit.target: Swagger endpoint

trans-unit.source: You can specify an endpoint that provides Swagger 2.0 JSON metadata for an API app in a property of the API app.
trans-unit.target: You can specify an endpoint that provides Swagger 2.0 JSON metadata for an API app in a property of the API app.

trans-unit.source: The endpoint can be relative to the base URL of the API app or an absolute URL.
trans-unit.target: The endpoint can be relative to the base URL of the API app or an absolute URL.

trans-unit.source: Absolute URLs can point outside the API app.
trans-unit.target: Absolute URLs can point outside the API app.

trans-unit.source: Many downstream clients (for example, Visual Studio code generation and PowerApps "Add API" flow), the URL must be publicly accessible (not protected by user or service authentication).
trans-unit.target: Many downstream clients (for example, Visual Studio code generation and PowerApps "Add API" flow), the URL must be publicly accessible (not protected by user or service authentication).

trans-unit.source: This means that if you're using App Service authentication and want to expose the API definition from within your app itself, you need to use authentication option that allows anonymous traffic to reach your API.
trans-unit.target: This means that if you're using App Service authentication and want to expose the API definition from within your app itself, you need to use authentication option that allows anonymous traffic to reach your API.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Authentication and authorization for App Service API Apps](app-service-api-authentication.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Authentication and authorization for App Service API Apps](app-service-api-authentication.md).

trans-unit.source: Portal blade
trans-unit.target: Portal blade

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure portal](https://portal.azure.com/) the endpoint URL can be seen and changed on the **API Definition** blade.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure portal](https://portal.azure.com/) the endpoint URL can be seen and changed on the **API Definition** blade.

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager property
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager property

trans-unit.source: You can also configure the API definition URL for an API app by using Azure Resource Manager tooling such as Azure PowerShell, CLI or [Resource Explorer](https://resources.azure.com/).
trans-unit.target: You can also configure the API definition URL for an API app by using Azure Resource Manager tooling such as Azure PowerShell, CLI or [Resource Explorer](https://resources.azure.com/).

trans-unit.source: Set the `apiDefinition` property on the Microsoft.Web/sites/config resource type for your
trans-unit.target: Set the `apiDefinition` property on the Microsoft.Web/sites/config resource type for your

trans-unit.source: /web resource.
trans-unit.target: /web resource.

trans-unit.source: For example, in **Resource Explorer**, go to **subscriptions > {your subscription} > resourceGroups > {your resource group} > providers > Microsoft.Web > sites > {your site} > config > web**, and you'll see the cors property:
trans-unit.target: For example, in **Resource Explorer**, go to **subscriptions > {your subscription} > resourceGroups > {your resource group} > providers > Microsoft.Web > sites > {your site} > config > web**, and you'll see the cors property:

trans-unit.source: Default value
trans-unit.target: Default value

trans-unit.source: When you use Visual Studio to create an API app, the API definition endpoint is automatically set to the base URL of the API app plus `/swagger/docs/v1`.
trans-unit.target: When you use Visual Studio to create an API app, the API definition endpoint is automatically set to the base URL of the API app plus `/swagger/docs/v1`.

trans-unit.source: This is the default URL that the [Swashbuckle](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Swashbuckle) NuGet package uses to serve dynamically generated Swagger metadata for an ASP.NET Web API project.
trans-unit.target: This is the default URL that the [Swashbuckle](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Swashbuckle) NuGet package uses to serve dynamically generated Swagger metadata for an ASP.NET Web API project.

trans-unit.source: Code generation
trans-unit.target: Code generation

trans-unit.source: One of the benefits of integrating Swagger into Azure API apps is automatic code generation.
trans-unit.target: One of the benefits of integrating Swagger into Azure API apps is automatic code generation.

trans-unit.source: Generated client classes make it easier to write code that calls an API app.
trans-unit.target: Generated client classes make it easier to write code that calls an API app.

trans-unit.source: You can generate client code for an API app by using Visual Studio or from the command line.
trans-unit.target: You can generate client code for an API app by using Visual Studio or from the command line.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to generate client classes in Visual Studio for an ASP.NET Web API project, see [Get started with API Apps and ASP.NET](app-service-api-dotnet-get-started.md#codegen).
trans-unit.target: For information about how to generate client classes in Visual Studio for an ASP.NET Web API project, see [Get started with API Apps and ASP.NET](app-service-api-dotnet-get-started.md#codegen).

trans-unit.source: For information about how to do it from the command line for all supported languages, see the readme file of the [Azure/autorest](https://github.com/azure/autorest) repository on GitHub.com.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to do it from the command line for all supported languages, see the readme file of the [Azure/autorest](https://github.com/azure/autorest) repository on GitHub.com.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: For a step-by-step tutorial that guides you through creating, deploying, and consuming an API app, see [Get started with API Apps in Azure App Service](app-service-api-dotnet-get-started.md).
trans-unit.target: For a step-by-step tutorial that guides you through creating, deploying, and consuming an API app, see [Get started with API Apps in Azure App Service](app-service-api-dotnet-get-started.md).
